sect1.title: Monitoring Clusters
sect1.para: &hawk2; has different screens for monitoring single clusters and multiple clusters: the Status and the Dashboard screen.

sect2.title: Monitoring a Single Cluster
sect2.para: To monitor a single cluster, use the Status screen. After you have logged in to &hawk2;, the Status screen is displayed by default. An icon in the upper right corner shows the cluster status at one glance. For further details, have a look at the following categories:

listitem.para: Only shown if errors have occurred.

Shows the configured resources including their Status, Name (ID), Location (node on which they are running), and resource agent Type. From the Operations column, you can start or stop a resource, trigger several actions, or view details. Actions that can be triggered include to set the resource to maintenance mode (or remove maintenance mode), migrate it to a different node, clean up the resource, show any recent events, or edit the resource.

Shows the nodes belonging to the cluster site you are logged in to, including the nodes' Status and Name. In the Maintenance and Standby columns, you can set or remove the maintenance or standby flag for a node. The Operations column allows you to view further details, for example, if a utilization, standby or maintenance attribute is set for the respective node.

sect2.title: Monitoring Multiple Clusters
sect2.para: To monitor multiple clusters, use the &hawk2; Dashboard. The cluster information displayed in the Dashboard screen is stored on the server side and synchronized between the cluster nodes (if passwordless SSH access between the cluster nodes has been configured). For details, see . However, the machine you are running &hawk2; on does not even need to be part of any cluster for that purpose—it can be a separate, unrelated system.
In addition to the general , the following prerequisites need to be fulfilled to monitor multiple clusters with &hawk2;:

listitem.para: All clusters to be monitored from &hawk2;'s Dashboard must be running &productname; &productnumber;.

If you did not replace the self-signed certificate for &hawk2; on every cluster node with your own certificate (or a certificate signed by an official Certificate Authority), log in to &hawk2; on every node in every cluster at least once. Verify the certificate (or add an exception in the browser to bypass the warning).

procedure.title: Monitoring Multiple Clusters with the Dashboard

step.para: From the left navigation bar, select Dashboard.
To add dashboards for multiple clusters, click Add Cluster.
Enter a custom Cluster name with which to identify the cluster in the Dashboard.
Enter the Hostname of a node in the cluster.
To specify further options such as the update interval for &hawk2;, the port to connect to, or whether to use HTTPS (default), click Advanced and enter the details.
To add more clusters to the dashboard, click Add Cluster again and enter the details for the next cluster.
To remove a cluster from the dashboard, click the x icon next to the cluster's name.
To view details about a cluster, enter a password and click Connect.

&hawk2; shows you a summary with the status of the respective nodes, resources, and tickets.
Clicking a cluster name will take you to the Status view for that cluster, from where you can administer it as usual.
